Senior management lacks of prospective of future -- all they care about are meeting this year's KPI. Even though they are yelling that make difference to achieve PC+ goal on the press, in reality they just want to meet sales target and ensure their bonus, in scarification of product competence, profit margin, cash flow, and employee benefit. 
In Lenovo, if you are already a manager, then it is good for you because all you are going to do is attending meetings, con-calls, which may not constructive or even matters at all. You can just ensure you can use your mouth, phones, Lync software, then leave all the work to your employees. This is indeed the 'management' profile in Lenovo, despite of  which level of management you are. Put yourself in this situation and image that you are the manager of Lenovo, you wont leave you position because although your salary is slightly below the average, the efforts you make is minimum, compared with peers of other companies-- how cost-effective it is!
Low pay and benefit, all-day-long-work, and very limited promotion space create huge turnover, and the company is still cutting budget on benefit and firing employees.

review_title: Dynamic environment and one of the Best Places to Work
pros: A dynamic and autonomous working environment, although this mostly depends on the group and management that you work with/for, but Lenovo encourages this work environment and it is evident across multiple teams.  Most employees are very passionate about their work, which is contagious.  Good overall compensation packages and very attractive benefits offerings (onsite Wellness Center, free gym facilities on both campuses).  While every organization has business controls, Lenovo runs fairly flat for an organization of it's size.  They also recognize good performance outside performance reviews.  There is a misconception with many that they are just an extension of IBM, which is not true.  They are more progressive, employee friendly and rewarding.  Just named the Best Place to Work by NCTA for 2015.
cons: It's an entrepreneurial environment with a large/enterprise organization backing it....which may be looked at as a positive or negative.  This means in order to get your job completed, there might be additional hours, engagement with China during off hours, etc.  Again, much of this depends on your responsibility in the organization.  Recent acquisitions have resulted in some internal disorganization, but there seems to be more clarity moving forward.

pros: Work/Life Balance can decent, as long as you don't have too many late night or early morning calls.
cons:
I have been very disappointed with my tenure at Lenovo. 

On my first day on the job, I was surprised to learn that I had been re-assigned to a different team then I had interviewed with. There isn't much direction on the team I'm assigned to, and I've probably only spoken to my manager, about 4 times in the past 3 months.

I've found that instead of working together, many of the internal teams appear to be in direct competition with each other. There is way too much political back and forth for me at Lenovo. As, an engineer, I want to work hard and want to contribute to the company, but I feel like I am held back by the politics and the lack of an engineering culture. The work that has been done by the existing team, is of very poor quality. This is further validated, as the manager of my team appears to prioritize Cheap and Fast, over Good. The work that the existing team has done, is not stored in source control and there is no Dev or Test environment, everything has to be done in production.

review_title: Nice place for a "Job" but not necessarily a career.
pros:
Reasonable pay relative to marketplace. Chance to work for a company with a rich history in the PC space. Also generally thought to have the best notebook product in the commercial marketplace. 

Many of the people you work with in sales are top notch. Great place to learn selling if you are from another technical field (IT, engineering, etc...). 

Great deal of responsibility given to account reps to manage their assigned customer set/territory. Thus if you want a degree of independence this may be a good company to work in account management(at least in that respect).

Rest of company really revolves around sales force - which is as it should be!
cons: Poor operational performance hampers company's ability to truly grow and steal share from competitors.

pros: Laid back work environment, okay salary, flexible work hours.
cons: Management throughout the admin center is very poor. The managers are never even around to see what the admin's are doing or the hard work that they are putting into their job. I had 17 directors that I was supporting. The only thing that my manager cared about was the feedback that she was receiving from 2 of the directors. I felt very discriminated against because of how I looked and what I wore. I would dress business professional every day, and I felt as if I were looked down upon because of this. They didn't take me seriously. My manager also said several things to me that made me feel like I wasn't intelligent enough to be successful within this position. It's almost like she wanted to knock down my self-esteem. They pick favorites and it is very much so like high school. Stay away from this position and the admin center at Lenovo. If you do not fit in, you will be looked down upon.

pros: Travel and sometimes you can make your own hours but it doesn't make up for the punishing workload and awful management elsewhere. Some of the most genuine coolest coworkers I could have asked for.
cons:
Corruption and funding a government that systematically imprisons and censors political dissidents. A department received an HR award for assisting provincial police departments in China with surveillance software used against its citizens. Racism against non-chinese employees of all races and nationalities. Management has an inflated sense of self-worth with no consideration for many employees. Constant talk of opportunity for growth but none ever materialize. Double speak, political games and back stabbing. Complete ineptitude at technical disciplines within the marketing field. Absolutely no hard analysis of marketing data to direct strategy for company. We would just "do stuff because it seemed cool" to our leadership (who had no hard skills and simply talked in vague business speak). Complete disregard for hard work, while suck-ups benefitted. Real condescending, snake-in-the-grass management. I was punished for doing real work and drawing attention to weaknesses at the company.

I was never paid in parity with my coworkers. Management kept holding out the possibilities of raises and promotions for almost 3 years only to go back on their word or say "I never said that."

review_title: I worked at Lenovo France for almost half a year in the Paris office
pros: Very fast growing company, with the acquisition of two large multinationals over the past 3 months. There are many projects, many new hires, and a new office in a few months. Definitely a lot to happen and career opportunitites for those who are comfortable in the company. There are good values and the company is adamant on applying them.
cons: Long, long working hours, a lot of work at home in the evenings and weekends (even during vacation if you dare to open your laptop), and very political. It is a chinese company, and it shows how companies work in the new world, and it is the opposite from state owned companies. Some departments are much better than others to work in, depending on the people. The company is a world leader but it still operates as a start up: no follow up for new hires, it is up to you to fight for every information/tip/process. There is so much work to be done that it is hardly impossible for other employees to dedicate time to your integration.

pros: The employees are very entrepreneurial and the products are very innovative.I love supporting and teaming with internal customers in all geographies. The IT support engineers from China are well trained and  each love working directly with US users. The Morrisville / Davis drive facilities are great including the staff supporting the cafeteria and on-site gym.
cons: The base pay is significantly below market rate and after working all day, you are expected to give up your evenings for conference calls. The benefits, bonuses and site office environment make up for some of the intrusion into your family time. Too much over head in management ranks leads to constant reorganization and conflicting direction/vision to staff.

job_title: Cloud Support Engineer in Durham, NC
pros: Good people to work. Friendly environment. A fairly open minded work atmosphere with freedom to accomplish your work in the manner the  works best for you. Nice working environment. Good team dynamics. Most people work in the office , with work from home option occasionally.  Availability and  quick response is more important than your physical location, but the team I worked on did a lot of in-person collaboration with other team members. So most people work in the office, because it's easier to just walk up to them and ask  a question.  Good focus on capitalizing on new technologies to bring new products to market. They the market leader in PC technologies.
cons: Not many con's. A great place to work. Sometimes people are only aware of that part of a project they are directly working on, and not how it fits into the project as a whole. But overall it's a great place to work.

pros: Generally decent people who mean well.
cons:
Specifically the data center group: lack of market awareness means tough slog to sell.  Suprisingly amateur; disfunctional systems, misguided senior management team, totally under resourced for the ambitions of the company. The lack of people means lots of very long days, exasibated by last century systems, and outsourced or overseas functions who frankly are not up to the job. It’s hard to compete in the market when you can’t provide competitive quotes to customers quickly, and delivery times can be 6-8 weeks. Onsite support poor too - it is outsourced to IBM with no SLA in place, so frequently have issues that IBM doesn’t fix as there’s no penalty to them. Many other issues like this are damaging the reputation of the company.
Most of the team is demotivated and looking elsewhere for jobs as the pressure rises with increased targets and diminishing resources.

pros: Great company for the employee who has no future.
cons:
Pumped us up with promises that we would be free from IBM issues.
Told us everything would be continued in the current locations.
I was part of the IBM sale of the x-series division to Lenovo. 
They basically took what they wanted, divested what they didn't, and layoffs came from that.
I would have liked to had the chance to work 2 more years and retire with 30 years from IBM.
Instead, I lost a lot of retirement money and was unemployed.  The whole mess just stunk!
They should have been up front from the start, and let us transfer to other jobs within IBM since they had no plans to keep us anyway.   Instead we were forced to go to Lenovo.

review_title: Great products, poor management and talent recognition
pros:
- Can honestly say that the products are great, buy them myself for my family
- There are good perks ... in general, benefits are on basically on par with similar companies
- Flexibility at work is fairly good, especially when life issues happen.
cons:
- Poor talent recognition and proper compensation. It's very clear how rewards are done based on management preferences versus actual workload and achievements.
- After resource reductions, remaining employees have to absorb other jobs ... for free. Even when after hours work (night conf calls) might increase significantly.
- Changing jobs within the company is hardly ever financially attractive
- Moral is at all times low, many people in important roles are looking for other jobs

review_title: The Best Company I've worked for...!!
pros: Great Workplace, Great Pay and Great Compensations. At Leadership / all levels, one is not expected to await directions all the time but to align and run with the Organizational Goals and Objectives. I was fortunate to contribute to core Teams that eventually reached Lenovo India and Lenovo Globally to no. 1 position. A memorable stay of almost 4 years...!!
cons: Strategically, Lenovo has probably thrived on High Growth plans, deep desire to sustain on top and keep improving Profitability. Such consistent approach could shorten careers for those who reserve their commitment levels short of 200%.

review_title: Not a great place for a career, but could be a good J O B
job_title: Global Commodity Manager in Morrisville, NC
pros: Depending on where you land in the company, potential for great work/life balance. Lenovo just started summer hrs which means work from home on Friday afternoon, and no meetings allowed. Bonuses were great this year, but that's an exception in this industry.
cons:
No promotions for US employees, regardless of how well you perform. All non-management employees I know in 25-40 age group are unhappy, in all functions, so it's not limited to Procurement. No career opportunities, although there is a lot of talk of talent & retention. 
Most employees are hit with a difficult schedule of late evening and early morning calls to work with China.Oh, yes, another thing: Lenovo went through inflation of titles. Almost all first line managers are now called Directors. Also, a bunch of "program directors" out there...

review_title: Strong people, yet incompetent and reactive leadership who fail to understand market dynamics outside of China
pros: The people at Lenovo are fantastic.  Hard working, dedicated, passionate about the work and willing to help others.  However, Lenovo is its own worst enemy and can't get out of its own way.
cons:
Leadership's China-centric view coupled with highly-tenured leaders who have never worked outside of China or Lenovo prevent true innovation required within the high-tech sector.  

The process, systems and hierarchy required for any decision or approval stifles quick decision making when working with smaller and highly innovative partners. 

Finally, the hours at Lenovo, regardless of role or level are brutal.  Coupled with ongoing reductions, cuts to any development except for executives, and ongoing thanklessness from leadership for expected extra project work, morale is terrible and key people are leaving in droves.

review_title: It is just a matter of time before everything implodes!!
pros: Great benefits!  Very collaborative work environment.
cons:
There is a serious "lack of continuity" at Lenovo.  

Constant layoffs on a yearly basis.

Frequent reorganizations within business units. 

Way too many "experienced workers" are being cut and their jobs are being off-shored to other countries for "cheaper labor"   

Constant budgeting problems 

No work/life balance for employees due to the ever increasing workloads. 

Unrealistic goals set by the executives.  

Numerous slips in project schedules due to a serious "lack of resources".   

It is completely "point-less" to fill out "Lenovo Listens" surveys because none of the employees' concerns are taken seriously by management.  It is just a total waste of time.  

The cafeteria food is lousy and overpriced!!  

Too much of the "IBM culture" still exists at Lenovo.  

Not a good company for those seeking long-term employment.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: I had good 5 years of employment with this company during which I learned a lot of new tools and technologies. I started as a consultant there, but been proposed to convert to a full time because of my significant contributions to the project. I met there some extremely talented people, who now mostly moved to CA, WA or TX to work for Google, Facebook, Apple or Amazon.  It was great to use some new Google technologies before they were advertised for other Google clients (Motorola was a Google company at that time).
cons:
Very shaky and unstable situation with the company revenues. Constant layoffs. Managers are a protected class while employees have to suffer for bad management decisions. Not AGILE environment (by the time when I left at least).
Life/Work balance is not great, a lot of overtimes and very little or no recognition for achievements. Upper management changes sometimes meant 180 degrees turns in product development decisions.

pros: Great team, loyal and hardworking
cons:
Very weak HR leader - resulting in poor support for managers and team, consistent failure to deliver as promised.  

Lack of significance placed on back office functions, instead huge sales drive and focus.  

Consistent feelings of neglect amongst team members outside of sales - no funds for team meetings, team events etc whilst sales have constant succession of rewards that are publicly highlighted - need to balance this much better or at least help managers maintain motivation in non sales functions! 

Pressure to deliver more, more, more with constantly reducing staff levels and resources.  

Extremely poor work life balance for managers and team

Work from home initiative to support work/life balance not supported AT ALL by all functional leaders!  Lack of trust...

Good salary / bens when joining but becomes quite static for all employees once you're in the company, very difficult for management to reward employees sufficiently and therefore impossible to retain top talent

review_title: Lenovo is not what it was 2 years ago
pros: People, Location, Experience, On-site Gym, On-site Medical Center
cons:
Politics
Harassment
Poor Executive Management
No Work/Life Balance
Vacation (up to Mgmt. discretion - not guaranteed)
No Marketing discipline advancement opportunities

review_title: Lenovo DCG (Data Center Group) work environment. Very positive experience, flexible work/life environment
job_title: Senior Computer Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Excellent benefits, engaging environment, work-life flexibility, plenty of opportunities for engaging internal and external  activities. Managers inform their team of other job opportunities within the company, possibly at the expense of committed projects.  Management trusts mid/senior engineers appropriately. (Minimal observation of unwarranted  "micro-management").  Top-tier engineers are rewarded financially through pay increases and semi-annual pay bonuses.  Pay is reported as above average when compared to salaries of senior engineers for other local companies... However, my personal interactions with other senior engineers in the RTP / Raleigh area suggest the average salary reported by Glassdoor and other summaries are significantly lower than my experience and conversations with engineers with similar skills would report.
cons: Layoffs *can* be more frequent than other companies, and may include long-term employees that are considered highly skilled engineers.

review_title: Was part of IBM divestiture, then offered a buyout
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Morrisville, NC
pros: Despite what happened to my position and situation, Lenovo has a very vibrant, upbeat feel compared to IBM.  They are full bore investing in R&D in PC's, tablets, low-end servers (which no one else is, at least not to the degree Lenovo is) and coming out with some great products, thus having earned #1 market share worldwide on the PC side.  Looks like they're heading that way with the servers and mobile phones now, too.
cons: Obviously, being offered a package shortly after having been sold to and onboarded by Lenovo was a bit of a shock, although the package was decent.  I have to believe that was orchestrated by IBM to some degree.  While not as silo'd by product lines as IBM, it is very silo'd by Geo which would seem to weaken advantages of scale when launching new products and programs.

review_title: Great experiences, but don't expect stability or work-life balance
pros: Great place to grow quickly if you are confident and effective at working independently. Very collaborative and minimal politics below the executive ranks.  Great global group of talented people.
cons:
Company runs ridiculously lean, systematically under investing in every function.  It has big ambitions but does not commit resources or make trade offs necessary to fully achieve the vision. People regularly face gaps between management expectations and what is realistically achievable with resources invested. 

To survive and succeed, people must continually work long hours and skillfully triage their work. With almost no backup or redundancy,  PTO can often be disrupted.   Very high stress working to keep up in an understaffed organization.  

Continuous reorganization is a way of life so difficult to find stability in processes, key interfaces or performance expectations.

pros:
I joined Lenovo when it started operations in Latin America, so it was a thriving new company here, amazing to work in because everything was yet to be done. Over the 10 years I worked there, the company grew a lot and many things changed, but for me it was always a pleasure to be part of Lenovo.
I worked from home on a permanent basis for 7 years, doing what I love and studied hard to do, which is translate, with an amazing team under my management
cons:
Lots of changes all the time, we usually were changed from one manager to another, from one region to another, there were two big layoffs and the staff usually changed. 
Also, at least during my years in the company, the salaries were a bit low, considering our years of experience and hard work. And the famous "curve" at evaluating performance left us more than once vulnerable because we were a minority team within the company

pros: The end user device range is good.
cons:
Lenovo is a traditional chinese company in every sense; copy what everyone else is doing, just do it cheaper.

Don't let the marketing fool you, there's no thought leadership nor any research and development. Internal systems and processes are shunned in favour of hiring additional Chinese resources without the required skills.
This translates to a slow moving bureaucracy like no other. If you're ok with that, whether or not you should accept an offer depends on which division it's in. 
In the personal systems, there's a good chance you'll have a good run. It's an established market and Lenovo's device range is pretty good. If it's in the Data Center division however, run for your life. 
On top of the aforementioned issues, you'll be bogged down by chronic lack of resources, immature and inexperienced management combined with unreachable goals. 

Do your due diligence and take notice how the average tenure is below 2 years, there's a reason for that.

review_title: Too many changes, loss of talent
pros: Nice people. Good friends.  Commissions were great a few years ago... Easy to make six figures as an inside rep at that time.
cons: Commission structure changes constantly and for the worse, year by year.  Micro-management. Very open workplace means you will constantly get sick.  Managers use their influence to try to sell you "home party" clothes and jewelry.  The company only hires brand new college grads now and as a result much less talent.  Senior leadership is all men, no diversity.

job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Job security, okay benefits, get to work from home
cons:
The culture is China-centric. Chinese employees get better bonuses than US employees. Promotions don't happen.

The company expects you to put Lenovo before your personal life -- one of their mottos is "Prioritize the Company." They layed off essential employees and "replaced" them with less competent Chinese employees. You can't get promoted because upper management won't let our immediate management backfill any vacated jobs. Somehow upper management can find the money to hire more upper management.

As if that isn't enough, the office is noisy (due to construction outside and above us), has very little privacy, and almost no parking. We don't have a cafeteria or gym in our building the way Morrisville does, and we're treated as unimportant by upper management. We hear about things done for Morrisville employees, but we're treated like upper management doesn't want anyone to know we (or our products) exist. The company won't even put its name on the building!

review_title: Ivory tower working....completely devoid of reality
pros: Very process oriented, casual clothing, everyone is very approachable
cons:
- sr managers have a very negative mindset. they will not remember the good work but will definitely latch on to one work which was missed.
- tooooooooo much meetings. I became a ppt specialist.....
- extremely trade focused.
- 80% time is spent on strategy & 20% on execution. It should be the other way round.
- When a strategy is made, be patient & wait for it to yield results. Dont panic at the first sign of less sales.
- NO WORK LIFE BALANCE. In the first 6 months of my joining, i would have rarely enjoyed a Sunday (leave alone a saturday). Worse your SLM expected such long hours.

review_title: Great benefits and pay, friendly colleagues
job_title: R&D in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
The pay is higher than average for the area and the bonus structure is often very generous.

The benefits are better than most other companies in the area with a great 401K matching plan
cons:
The executive leadership is not great. Many of the EDs and VPs are in that role because they have been there for so long, not because it was earned or deserved.  Many do not make decisions that are best for the long term or future of the company.  

Lenovo does not want to invest time and resources in advancing their products, no chances are taken and oftentimes leadership does not listen to customer needs and wants.  Their customer and user experience is by far one of the worst in the industry

review_title: Best place to kick-start your professional career
pros: You get to know the ins and outs of the business from the world's leading PC manufacturer. There's a lot of transformation that has happened in the way Lenovo functions today as compared to the traditional IBM days. Focus is more on creating smart devices, ecosystems, and solutions for customers, along with finding those disruptive innovations, that allow Lenovo to challenge the status quo. Along with that, Lenovo is a great place for a collaborative, respectful, and non-micromanaging work environment. Everyone is super welcoming and trustworthy, it feels like a way of life and you never feel that you are on a job.
cons: If you are not a fan of open offices, then it might be the only downside here. The organization is long done with the cubicle-like work environment to allow everyone easy access to the leadership teams and their managers. Also, nobody feels left out on an open floor. Just invest in a nice pair of noise-canceling headphones and everything will be sorted.

pros:
I used to have a lot of them, but as we have grown they have mostly all gone away. 

Flexible Schedule
Open Vacation
Good Products
cons:
Poor Leadership or Absent Leadership
Millennial Invasion
Company Politics
Nepotism
Lack of career opportunities  
Poor pay compared to market

review_title: Recidulous amount of changes for the worse
job_title: Data Center Group in Great Falls, MT
pros: Executives are doing very well for themselves
cons: Began as a focused company that operated as a team approach for the customer.  A couple of years back this changed, divisions split (copying HP, IBM, etc) and went from a single quarterback for the account to 7 different individuals all with different management infrastructure, and no communication or oversight between the various groups.  Then began a rapid increase in internal calls, training, etc which cut approx 12 hours out of the work week, just to attend mandatory internal calls.  On top of that, just about every week, a new report or metric was introduced which had not been seen before.  Internal tracking was done via a dozen different 3rd party websites, which were not intuitive and very cumbersome.  Add to this, the group meetings, some executive would get in front of us and show a slide that stated "One Lenovo" nothing could be further from the truth!

review_title: Fast growing brand in a low profit industry, need to continue cultural change
pros:
- good salary and bonus package
- flexible work location 
- strong consumer segment growth
- strong business momentum
cons:
- The organization is too hierarchal, which drives a lot of negative behavior such as not taking responsibility and office politics and de-motivates junior staff.  
- The culture is too driven by Chinese senior leadership, the company is still too Chinese to be a top rated workplace for international professionals
- A lot of office politics and job advancement is very slow
- Still a male oriented senior leadership team

review_title: Management needs to learn that your people is your biggest asset.  Until that happens, things will not improve.
pros:
Global experience - plenty of opportunity to work with people all over the world like China, Japan, India, Mexico, Brazil, Europe (Hungary, ie).  Many positions require travel (esp to China).  Also opportunity for short-term or long-term assignments abroad.

Work/life flexibility - people are treated as professionals to manage their own time.  As long as your work is done, they are not clocking your time.  Also allow you to utilize PC for personal business (with access to virtually any website).  

good benefits - health/dental insurance is average, 401K match is good, disability benefits are good, on-site gym & cafeteria, some "off cycle" prizes for good performance
cons: poor management, don't value internal talent, although "worldsourcing" is a company value - most U.S. employees must be in NC (few remote workers)

review_title: No clear direction. Jobs moving to China.
pros: Nice facilities, competitive salary, benefit and bonus package is good. NC facility has fitness center and cafeteria.
cons: Constant re-organizations and realignment of business units, along with predictable cycles of layoffs and jobs being moved to China have left a demoralized and insecure workforce in place. There's a complete lack of focus, no long term plan, and the company never follows through with any of their initiatives or programs. We spend more time working on presentations for VP's than we do performing actual work.  China's VP's value input from consultants more than their own management.

review_title: If you just need a short-term position Lenovo may be OK. Don't consider them for a career position.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Average salary & benefits. Decent technical people.
cons: Lenovo is Chinese owned so jobs are constantly moving to China. This means that you have little or no job security. The first and second line management do not know how to manage software technology and continue to think you can make last second changes to code bases and not obsolete all the testing you have already done. Everything is run by comittee and everyone thinks they can tell the development team what to do. There is no clear decision making ability. The experience level has dropped way off since IBM sold the PC business to Lenovo. Most first and second line managers are simply playing a political game to hang on to thier own jobs.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Morrisville, NC
pros:
In the year I have worked at Lenovo, I have been amazed at how fast improvements are implemented. I will go into a meeting, a decision is made, a course is charted, and we're off and running. 

Lenovo has entered the era of big data and is leveraging it in thrilling ways that will have huge benefits for customer experience and the bottom of the line. I am impressed at how much other Lenovo employees care about the customer experience. 

Thinking out of the box is encouraged, and contributions are recognized. Overall, I am thrilled to work for Lenovo.
cons:
Slackers are not welcome. Bring your "A" game.
Life/work balance is blurry, but honestly, when putting in extra hours results in providing solutions to customers, it's worth the time.

pros: Great benefits, and some good ideas, but they steal them from you. DO NOT INNOVATE FOR LENOVO. THEY WILL CHEAT YOU!!!
cons: I am being laid off October 31, this year. I created, so far, 48 patents for Lenovo. They are now telling me when I am laid off I will not be paid for any patents that I have not signed over rights to. This totals around 30,000 dollars. So, they hired me a year and a half ago, exploited my intellectual property, and then laid me off, still owing me around 30,000 dollars for the patents. Not good business for a 'technology' firm. Do not expect to stick around if you get a job here.

review_title: LENOVO?? BE FRIENDS WITH YOUR MANAGER AND YOU'LL BE HAPPY!
pros: Comparable salaries, work enviornment, training material and experience
cons: Large company with the small business promotion process. You can only be promoted if you have a really close relationship with your first and second line managers. Doesn't really matter if you do your job well and have the passion for the business... the person who get's promoted is your manager's best friend. And it's not personal. I've seen it all throughout the departments and everyone comments about it. It's awfully dissapointing.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in Morrisville, NC
pros:
* Excellent facilities
* Goal oriented
* Dynamic work environment
* Good compensation and benefits package
* Transparency - executive management clearly communicates its direction and expectations on a regular basis
cons:
* Growing pains - still learning how its businesses (mobile, PC, data center) should interact and complement each other
* High market expectations - Lenovo leadership expects high margins, AND high market share, in a very challenging market, which historically has very low margins.

review_title: Incredible opportunities to learn about global business, but at a big hit to work/life balance
pros: Lenovo is a truly ground-breaking company - the first Chinese company to really go build a global brand.  If you want to gain first hand experience on what has propelled the Chinese economy over the last decade plus, Lenovo's non-sales teams (corporate functions such as product development, product marketing, supply chain, finance, etc.) provide a great opportunity to understand a Chinese company from the inside.
cons: Lenovo operates as a global company - key sites are all around the globe (North Carolina, Beijing, ShenZhen, Singapore, etc.) - so expect your work-life balance to take a hit as you'll be on the phone at all hours of the day.

review_title: Unstable but treat good employees well
pros: Good employees are treated well.  Base compensation is reasonable (not great), but incentive plans, including pay for performance and long-term-incentive structure is good.  With the right boss, there is a lot of flexibility to work from home.
cons: Some extremely smart people, but Chinese culture can be difficult and cumbersome.  Processes and infrastructure are inefficient to say the least.   Extremely unstable environment.  Industry is not doing well, stock is plummeting, and in turn, there are layoffs every six months....almost to the date.  Very difficult to get promoted internally in this company.  Upward mobility is dismal.

review_title: Company energy is consumed by internal disputes
job_title: Anonymous Employee in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Company vision, Product quality (think product family) and financial acumen.
cons:
Internal disputes between different areas of the organization lead to suboptimal performance. Regional executives fighting for more power and climbing in the leadership ranks drive unrealistic targets that are not sustainable leading to operational failures. This results in regular changes in local leadership for not achieving the results in a consistent basis.  One evidence of this is that during 14 years of operation in Brazil, the company already had a total of 8 different Brazil general managers !!! 
Humans resources is very poor and limited. There are no strategic plans to develop a winning culture.

review_title: Run, don't walk, away from this company
pros: Still a young company, so you have a fair amount of freedom to try new things
cons:
China, China, China - it's all about China and Chinese culture - and eventually anyone not from China will be replaced
No room for advancement - terrible career planning, very little mobility, stuck in same job forever
Constantly shifting direction from leadership
Extremely hierarchical - if you aren't an Executive Director or above, your opinion does not matter
Hero worship of leadership - they can do no wrong
Skimpy raises

pros: Very supportive, promotion from within and room for advancement, very fun energy and place to work, events and social gatherings, great benefits.  Unlimited vacation is great.  It's a nice option to not "count the days" but after a few years of having it you just feel able to use it if you want to but not abuse it.  Nice to be able to say yes to a few more 1-2 day things during the year - a ski trip, a family or child's event, etc. but it's not abused.
cons: Not much bad to say.  You will reap what you sew.  Work hard and you are treated with respect and given .  You work hard, but you are granted flexibility if you show your value and "own your business"

review_title: Lenovo: So Much Potential but Ultimately Dysfunctional
pros: Salaries and benefits. Opportunity to work with some smart and talented people.
cons: Upper management came from IBM and brought a lot of bureaucratic practices with them. There are way too many meetings with many teleconferences being at night with colleagues in Asia. The organizational structure is cumbersome and top heavy with decision making pushed to the top. The PC business is one of the toughest on the planet and Lenovo is not set up for quickly responding to the unrelenting techhnology and market changes

review_title: Company is very geared towards Acquisition and Growth.  Doesn't
pros: Young atmosphere. Can be lucky and get placed in a good territory and constantly blow out your number, compensation is fairly competitive.  Overall you get good experience working with a brand name company.  Summer hour half days, get a good amount of vacation days.
cons: Inside Managers are hit or miss.  Territories are the same,  there is generally more opportunity for growth/compensation for acquisition--but you don't get to choose. High workload--often have to work nights and weekends to keep up (depending on territory).  Incentives are OK, could be better.  Are led to believe that advancement will be easy--It is definitely not.

pros: Strong culture, good people, Thinkpad is a very respected brand with a long standing reputation for high quality. HR do their best to make staff feel valued and provide perks like birthday leave, plenty of opportunity to make good money in sales.
cons: Complete lack of leadership. Middle management simply act as a conduit to the next level of management while beating their teams with a stick for more sales. Like many large companies some of the systems & processes in place are cumbersome & slow. Tasks are driven by KPIs and metrics which is frustrating when you have to stop doing something productive to do what management would like you to do. Major ongoing concern about work life balance in the sales team.

pros: If you need a job and you can't get in anywhere else then take it and hope for the best.
cons:
Weird company and culture.  Chinese culture all the way, centralized Chinese infrastructure, the individual doesn't matter.  Constant upheaval and reductions in staff, reorganizations, absolutely no stability.  This company can't figure out what to do and it makes changes every quarter or two.   Some people have been there a decade as they got absorbed from the IBM acquisition.  Lenovo has been greatly affected by their bad billion dollar purchases of Motorola and IBM Server business and are panicking.  China economy crashing only makes their outlook worse.  They just cut a bunch of staff, with much more to come again soon.

Working for this company has been awful and it was a bad career move for me.  Don't believe the hype out there

pros:
- Very strong CEO and Executive Committee with a clear strategy that is aggressive yet achievable
- Employees are some of the strongest I have seen that can execute in a very complex matrix environment
- Excellent culture to truly innovate and test
- Great benefits (401k match, EDCP, health, dental, vision)
- Awesome bonus structure
cons:
- Work life balance can be challenging.
- Burnout potential sooner than other companies within the same industry given the idea to get more done with less
- Lack of WW alignment between Global and Geos

review_title: Loved my team members, but did not like any management who were only concerned about their career and nothing else.
pros: Loved the strong team I worked with in Mobile Software Test and Development. We supported and encouraged each other to strive for a better and more efficient work environment with each project and task.
cons: Not all teams were as strong or flexible as ours, so it is not across all departments. Management in most departments at the time were very disconnected and were only interested in their own growth and accomplishments - no management support at all.

review_title: Phenomenal company to work for, be ware of DCG division
pros: People first is a real thing.  If you perform well at your role, you are encouraged to have a vision of where you want to go and support to get there.  Very good benefits including onsite gym and medical services.  Human Resource Groups that support diversity.  Quality products and a genuine culture of integrity and desire to change the world.
cons: The Datacenter Group (DCG) is at an entrepreneurial stage which can be exciting but the strategy is unclear which makes execution challenging and leadership appear weak.

review_title: Fast paced, hard charging, not for the weak
pros: Incredibly global company with a flat-world orientation that places it at the forefront of international management theory and implementation. The company's committment to R&D distinguishes itself from the commodity pack of PC manufacturers. It's quality committment, exemplified in the ThinkPad line as well as its emphasis on emerging markets stemming from its Chinese heritage (Legend Computer) makes Lenovo a hotbed of technology innovation.
cons: Global orientation makes the hours long. Controlled chaos is the best way to describe the culture. It is not for everybody, especially people who need a high degree of process and management oversight. If you are not a self-starter, you are not going to succeed at Lenovo.

pros: Best in class products. Focused brand team. Very energetic marketing team that wants to bring new and exciting products to market. Equitable compensation. Good benefits. Good and friendly people.
cons: Inconsistent management message. Changes happen, but changes each and every quarter means they are just looking for the magic formula to grow for growth's sake. Information is used as weapon. Internal systems absolutely suck. Any good experience a customer has had was because they had a good employee taking care of them that understood how to get around the system.

review_title: Great to work for a company dedicated to win
job_title: Global Program Manager in Morrisville, NC
pros:
Company constantly ahead of the curve and adjusts strategy to win
A great amount of autonomy, employees are trusted
Never a lack of work
Teams are small, make much more of an impact
Open to new ideas
Dedication to innovation is high
CEO always has very clear objective and vision
Amazing turnaround from unknown company to global leader going from #4 to #1 in 2 yrs....and now looking to move into smartphones.
Excellent Branding

Global roles can be tough, due to off hour calls and back and forth via email
Processes are not always clearly defined, sometimes causing duplicating work already done
Daily job can be reactive at times due to heavy email, because teams are small.
May get burnout if you don't work with your manager when workload gets too high.

review_title: At Lenovo your career path is made up of scrambling from lifeboat to lifeboat.
pros: Lenovo makes good products.  The base compensation package is ok but they have a good bonus program if you can get on your boss's good side long enough to earn one.  Some managers allow for flexible schedules.
cons: Terrible corporate structure.  I had 9 bosses in 5 years due to almost constant restructuring.  Impossible to develop rapport with coworkers and management.  In 3 consecutive years my role was outsourced to China and I was forced to search for another position.  There is a constant fear of layoffs.  Promotions are nonexistent.  Lots of evening conference calls to China.

pros:
-Decent health insurance / benefits

-work from home option in some areas
-
cons: Management gives pressure to innovate and share ideas and end up doing whatever the hell they want. All in all the benefits are the reason I don't leave but its tiresome to work for a company that's not very well organized and a bit hypocritical which is understandable based on IBM mgmt and being replaced w/chinese new generation mgmt... many managers promote the lower end employees to be able to get rid of them and hold back the good ones and won't allow progress.

pros:

pros: Lenovo has a strong work ethic, encourages participation in charitable events, flexible work schedule, allows you to manage balancing work and life, and has competitive wages.

Eventually, the work is piled so high, it becomes difficult to stay successful.

review_title: Great products and technologies.  Poor capacity to adjust to regional realities

Asian culture genrates difficult challenges locally

review_title: Not a good long term career choice, learn and move on.

Top jobs all chinese.

review_title: Lenovo is a fun, challenging place to work.
pros:
We get to be on the leading edge of technical development, and see how a company can take advantage of world sourced business.

cons: We work very long hours due to the global nature of our jobs. We also must learn to be sensitive to other cultures. Lenovo also has significant difficulties with our internal management of data. It is difficult, if not impossible, to track down important data needed to complete our jobs.

pros: Versatility in product, perpetual market as technology always changes and becomes outdated requiring consumers always to buy something new every few years.
cons: Poor communication between management and actual workers.  Employees are commodities.  Many managers have been with the company for 20 plus years with little exposure to the outside world of the company.  Inability to accept new ideas, and stubborn in defending their old and outdated operating model.

review_title: A long way to a globle company

review_title: Need to find their real culture among several different cultures behind
job_title: Senior Product Manager in São Paulo, São Paulo

You have opportunity to work with several different teams, in different locations, having direct contact with Chinese development team. 
Good pack of benefits.
cons:
Lots of changes in top management during a small period of time we had a Brasilian, a Chinese, an Italian, an Jewel and an American president with different ways of thinking and all of then were able to change everything in terms of business management and culture behaviour.

pros: The company is willing to help pay for training and give you experience in areas you'd like to transition into (if you want to make a move).

review_title: Extreme pressure, treats employees very disrespectfully.

Not much to admire in the management ranks, getting those positions is mostly political.  Managers are not typically leaders or motivational, instead they like to instill fear with frequent threats.

review_title: Not the worst place to work, but definitely not the best
pros:

pros: Great benefits all around. Great people. Didn't seem like there was much work, I had a lot of free time.

review_title: The Worse Company and Worse Job I have ever had---nothing comes close

review_title: Perpetually changing org charts and uncertain job security

cons: There was always an uncertainty about job security due to the constant re-orgs and possible paths of career progression were very limited.

review_title: Lenovo is a great place to work - unfortunate that previous exec administration spent so much money on the Olympics

cons: Lenovo hires a lot of contractors. The contractors they like and would like to keep are converted to Long-Term Supplemental Employees - which means you do not get to particpate in all of the benefits including P3 Bonus payouts.

review_title: Great Products, Horrible Culture,  Organizational nightmare
pros: They really do make the best computers in the industry (Think) products that is. Great working for a company that is rapidly growing especially in a declining industry.
cons: will not invest money in the company. They only spend money when they are in damage control never to invest in what they believe in. worked for roughly 5 years in sales -> Set quotas unrealistically high so that the company can still grow while paying employees nothing. Zero opportunities for internal growth -> They would rather bring in contract workers because they can pay them much less regardless if you have proven yourself for the role.

review_title: Happy Company with a Lot of Fun

Very happy environment
Employees very proud of what they do

cons: Dealing with IT is a nightmare, I am sure they know what they are doing but they are based in China and often you have to explain two or three times before they understand the issues. That having been said, it's usually possible to get the answers you need.

review_title: Much Potential, Lacking Support for Consistent Success
pros: Innovative products, broadening solution portfolio with vision for future of IT and business needs, great people and teamwork focus, decent workspace and resources to remain productive, nice facilities, positive impact to community with service and company-sponsored fund raising.
cons:
Inconsistent customer experience from: outsourced warranty service delivery with spotty global availability, growing trend of outsourcing underqualified clerical and operations support staff resulting in frequent careless errors and lack of accountability often due to no required proactive, direct interaction with clients, frequent shuffling of sales personnel with little foresight to impacting continuity of client relationships, underwhelming training programs for overwhelming day-to-day responsibilities, "sink or swim" approach with junior contractors often fresh out of college with little to no corporate work experience, unfocused product specialization = knowing a little (but rarely enough) about a LOT, limited support for complex solution selling, lack of world class IT platform for fast customer and partner service, erratic product strategy with marketing announcements that don't always come to fruition, often resulting in confusion and disappointment from siloed regional decision making and apparent lack of collaborative planning.

Inconsistent sales employee experience from: poor sales reporting necessitating weekly audits of sales attainment and time spent pursuing revenue with awkward reseller reporting requests long after a sale, whimsical and often unjustified quota setting, little time to properly profile an aged data dump within CRM platforms, no apparent analytics program to enable successful customer acquisition strategy, forecasting, or planning to effectively allow management to best understand the state of the business and respond accurately, redundant pricing controls and lack of rep-level delegation for fast quote turnaround on even the smallest of deals to best compete with competitors, shifting and often ambiguous roles, responsibilities, and expectations across sectors with little top-down enforcement, constant management re-orgs, new focus topic each week with daily spreadsheet fire drills and little to no understanding of "why," absentee leadership out of touch with diminishing employee morale from constant internal systems flaws and inefficiencies ultimately inhibiting ability to execute and cultivate customer relationships necessary to win.

All of the above = erosion of confidence in ability to deliver on commitments, both internally and externally as well as reduced credibility in the marketplace

pros: True global company - I've learned so much about different cultures around the world. Tons of smart people to learn from.
cons: A few years ago, I would've said this was the best place to work. Now, there is too much uncertainty and too much change (without a clear change management process in place). 2 rounds of layoffs this year with rumors of more at the beginning of the year. People are jumping ship. There is only a retention plan for Executives,,,nothing for managers or individual contributors. No career advancement - they would rather hire externally to quickly fill a gap.

pros: Lenovo offers an entrepreneurial environment that promotes free thinking and exploring new ways to get the job done.  Leadership supports new ideas and finding new ways to compete.  We have a culture of making big goals and fulfilling our commitments.
cons: At Lenovo, it sometimes takes extra work and working in a global company can mean hours that are not traditional.  Although Lenovo is a fast and dynamic work environment, the reward far outways the extra work we need to put in.

review_title: Lenovo is an interesting place to work with strategic challenges in a hyper competitive industry

review_title: Satisfaction varies by position and management

Depending on manager, work life balance will be stressful.

review_title: DCG business is beyond mediocrity, stay away unless you're desperate!
pros: Decent health benefits, good co-workers, unlimited vacation (ironically you can't fully take advantage of it if you're trying to sell on company's behalf).
cons: DCG executives can't seem to grow former IBM x86 server business's market shares and revenues quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year consistently.   Financials are manipulated to paint a rosy picture.  North America top executive changes every 2 yrs because revenues and profits (PCON) aren't growing at acceptable pace.  Sales quotas are delivered towards the end of the quarter once Mgt has a good idea where most deals will land to keep sales teams from overachieving revenue objectives and commission payouts. review_title: Good company that's so close to being great
pros:
Lenovo has a global, worldwide culture.  There are opportunities to explore different roles and areas of the business (if you're interested and motivated to do so).  The work environment varies based on where you're located but most are better than average compared to other companies in that geography.  

Compensation is fair and benefits are good, but not outstanding.  The company tries hard to engage employees, create excitement around the brand internally, and rally the troops.  

Employees are generally treated with respect, and most of the managers you'll encounter will help support your work-life balance as best they can, but this obviously varies.  We have a great CEO who is passionate about the company and is focused on the right things.

The work is fast-paced and challenging.  In most cases you and find a sense of fulfillment in the work you do and that you are contributing to the big picture.  Most teams are close-knit groups who bring you in and make you feel like part of a family.

There are a lot of activities, events, community service opportunities, sports outings, etc.
cons:
You can genuinely care about your job, want to succeed, and want to bring success to your organization at Lenovo, but unfortunately a large portion of the people you need to rely on to accomplish those goals will not share your passion, and you end up burning out as a result.  

There are a lot of under-qualified or completely unqualified people in key roles that are a drag on the rest of the team and they are rarely moved or fired due to performance.  There are many places to "hide" organizationally where you can under-perform, or have very little on your plate in terms of workload.  There are also smart, talented people who receive no training, guidance, or opportunity and are underutilized which is a shame.

At Lenovo, your skills in office politics will get you much farther than your job performance.  This is true in both the US and especially in China.

While you are treated with respect, you are still very much a bar code in the grand scheme of things.  HR partners cover hundreds of people and are generally unavailable to anyone under the Director level, and have piles of paperwork.  In 5+ years at the company I've had maybe 5-10 minutes of face time with HR, most of which took place during the interview process.  Time spent at the company is not valued, and you are no more/less valuable to the company than someone who can do your job and just walked in off the street.  I've also had serious issues that have gone ignored for almost a year.

The company is somewhat disorganized, processes are not optimized or even followed in some cases, and the solution to bottlenecks is usually to hire more people instead of solving the underlying issues, which just complicates things further.  

It seems like Lenovo would rather hire 10 people for $10k/year that make millions of dollars worth of mistakes than spend $100k on hiring 1 person who makes minimal mistakes, can actually handle the job they are assigned, and could save the company millions. This is especially true in China where average salaries are lower and there are more positions to fill.

Finally, while Lenovo has plenty of strategies and resources devoted to developing and implementing them, there is frequently no cohesion between organizations.  Different units/teams/etc. have conflicting KPIs and despite everyone having the same over-arching goals, no one is unified or aligned on how to achieve them.  The strategies themselves usually lack a concrete "how".  It's a lot of talk about vague "enhance this" or "improve that", with no mention of how this is going to happen.  At the end of the day the strategies just become words on paper.

pros:
Decent pay, good benefits, nice office in Morrisville, and generally speaking, most of my peers and immediate team were great to work with.  

Lenovo parties and events are interesting, and raffles and occasional special employee sales on hardware are also nice.

Once you get into vision, employee motivation, management, retention, work/life balance - I'd say it's highly BU/org dependent, but that leads into the cons.  It's also possible that you get lucky, as I worked with a lot of solid individuals that I enjoyed working with, but things really fall apart at mid and upper management in many cases.
cons:
Silos
Possibly with good reason initially, Lenovo let each brand and Geo more or less run things the way they wanted to.  This makes some sense during acquisitions or expanding product lines, but eventually needs to centralize again on things like standard services to customers, which software and systems are in use globally (except for China; literally worldwide = worldwide - China for various initiatives, policies, standards).  Often you would find different groups effectively "competing" against each other with similar initiatives, or with unclear expectations as each brand believes they are "priority one," or will go off to build another silo'd solution (why would anyone EVER fund such things?) while Sr. Mgmt. doesn't produce a top-down cohesive plan or vision - compounding this sort of issue further, costing money and time, and diluting customer experience along with internal effectiveness.

Reliance on IBM at any cost 
IBM obviously had the better lawyers in various agreements, to the point they make it nearly as expensive, or moreso, to move away from many long standing agreements with them.  Everyone knows the high relative costs there, but when new initiatives come up not covered by existing IBM agreements, inevitably some will try to push IBM as a solution provider, instead of looking into more cost effective and efficient options.  The reliance on IBM increases Lenovo's cost of doing business, which they decide to counter via random layoffs vs. smart business.  You also might be wise to point out the obvious inconsistencies and costs of partnering w/IBM, depending who you may be speaking with.  

Work/life balance
We get it, we're a global company, but there are ways to schedule meetings that limit the recurring evening (US time) meetings to 1-2 nights/week, instead dog perpetual ad-hoc until you realize you have several hours of meetings every night of the week, on top of your normal work days.  

Management
This may well have some dependency on where you work, and for whom.  Some Directors are solid, along with some Executive Directors, but often there's a never-ending cycle of "emergencies" that really aren't, often times created by some managing upwards/brown-nosing far more than considering team capacity, dwindling levels of motivation, or in some cases, putting personal "achievements" and reputation over the best interests of the company and team.  Throw in random initiatives that shouldn't exist at all coming in from China or other groups, and the possibility for chaos is fairly high until upper management sets a solid top-down vision and clear responsibilities across the company, IT and other teams.

pros:
The review title refers to a phrase I used to hear from time to time at Lenovo, used to describe the experience of working there. There is a lot of energy at Lenovo and a focus on the future. It's a young company and makes big moves. It moves quickly In this sense, it's like a startup. It's also a large, international company. This can obviously help the more nimble startup culture by providing capital and infrastructure, but it hindered Lenovo sometimes too, via bureaucracy and commitments to legacy systems.

Lenovo's employees are warm and helpful. They are smart and most care about the company in a real way. I worked with many professionals whom I respect and that is one of the best parts of working there.

In sales, one had considerable leeway to run things in one's territory as one saw fit. Management was open to new ideas and I implemented some of my own. Some failed, some succeeded;  the openness to new ideas is a testament to Lenovo's culture.

I am grateful to Lenovo and for the time I worked there. My experience there is defined by the fact that I didn't have extensive work history at the time of my hire; and working at Lenovo was my first experience working for a large corporation. Lenovo hired me soon after I graduated college and was open to taking a chance, which I'll never forget. I adapted well to the life of working at a large company. 

If you've worked at other companies and/or are coming in with a long resume, your mileage may vary. Lenovo is a great place to work that does have challenges; I would work there again if the right opportunity came along.
cons:
I did work through a contracting agency before being hired on full time. I was paid well and treated well. There was tension among people who got hired from the contractors' pool and as a contractor you weren't eligible to certain things like sales contests. I was treated as a member of the team and valued. There were just some annoying limits of being a contractor.

Lenovo consistently paid a little bit less across most jobs where I learned the salary against the industry. Pay can be a touchy subject for management but the fact is that not only was I miffed about my own pay towards the end of my stint; but competent, creative and innovative coworkers consistently left to take higher-paying jobs elsewhere. 

Speaking strictly regarding my time there there were manufacturing delays that put our shipping times well behind industry average. This was around the IBM x86 acquisition and year after it. It went on a long time. Global technology supply chains are incredibly complex. However, I think that considering that we faced serious problems for well over a year to the point that large sales were canceled and returned combined with the fact that Lenovo had many people whose expertise was global supply chains working on supply chains they themselves built, I think it's appropriate to criticize poor performance here. This was a political issue in my time. I have only my own observation that it was ongoing for a very long time and rumors I heard that certain senior managers were intransigent to change. Some had to be forged out to fix the problem, but this took a long time. I hope this has changed.

review_title: These guys are some of the best but some notes of caution.

These guys are going places, no doubt.  My belief is Lenovo's operational overhaul over the last 5 years has powered their marketplace success. Lenovo will be the #1 PC company within 5 years, I'm sure.   

It's a fantastic place to cut your teeth and see how a well-oiled Fortune 500 company runs.  Their leanness allows one to see all ends of the company, which is a rarity in most +$20B firms.
cons:
That said, it is still after all the PC industry they are battling in where margins are horrendous.  Consequently, squeezing blood from the stone has material impacts on the workforce - especially those who work in non-Low Cost Jurisdictions.  Obviously then, the employee base in North America & Western Europe is skeleton thin and the associated pressures apply.  

Wages are compressed in accordance with the aforementioned margin pressures, however with their record profits these past several quarters, one wonders what share of the profit the executive team is enjoying.

Personnel in many ways are seen as a necessary evil and certainly regarded as replaceable.  You won't find anything in their Lenovo Way culture document specifying the company's responsibility to, or appreciation for, the workforce. cons:
First I agree with about 99.9% of the cons of every other current & past employee. 

When I first started at Lenovo I truly loved my job and looked forward to a long career here. The sales team (at least the area that I was in), was respected and treated like we mattered. 

About 1-2 years after I started working there, there were some major changes to the organizational structure and two of the sales divisions were blended and that's when it all went downhill. In my 3.5 years at Lenovo I have literally had about 7 different managers and I have covered about 4-5 different territories. During this time I was "lucky" if I made my number. How could I actually work to make my number when I wasn't even in a territory long enough to remember the names of my account book's CIO's? (Luckily SOMEONE realized this was why reps were not making their number). We are treated as if we are completely dispensable and we are now being replaced by contractors who are underpaid and do not get anywhere near what a regular rep gets in commission. This I'm sure has a positive effect on the bottom line but a very negative effect on the workers. Not only the contractors who are not being treated fairly (and were lied to about the potential of their positions before being hired) but also the regulars who are becoming more of a financial liability instead of an asset.

Managers are hired based on who they have grown close to or what they could be holding over Lenovo's head (ie, possible HR issues). They preach about how they want to write big checks and reward overachievers, but when you overachieve they start raising your quota so that you don't achieve more than they want to pay you for and then if they allow you to "blow it out", they'll cap you in the end. Then the next qtr they double your quota so that you don't blow it out again or better yet not make your number at all so that they will reap the benefits of your revenue without having to pay you a dime for it. Either way Lenovo is going to try to get their money back. And then they wonder why reps sandbag...we have to be just as underhanded as management just to get a paycheck!  

Due to layoffs we have lost all of our resources and EVERYTHING lands on our laps and the inside team barely has a chance to prospect. We have ridiculous metrics, where we not only get to be so overworked that the majority of us are working at night and on the weekends but we also have to put in writing what we are doing. So we get to do and journal our work day. We are micromanaged and treated like little children who need to be kept on a short leash.

On many teams, employees are assigned a Lenovo ThinkPad to use.  The profit sharing bonuses are nice. They have an employee purchase discount on both the Lenovo PCs and Moto phones.  They have many community events such as assisting Habitat for Humanity, etc...  Ten years ago, they used to have free lunches to celebrate Thanksgiving and Christmas.  Technically you have unlimited vacation (with manager approval).  *****If you know the right people, work on a good team, and have a good manager, this is a great place to work.*****
cons: Some of the cons have been inherited from IBM - these include some inefficient structure and some software in some areas (Lenovo is making some attempts to change this).  As mentioned before, there's a lot of corporate politics in some groups and I feel that some of this came over from IBM (at least my retired IBM friends confirm this).  Some of the managers seem to fall into the category of "they were great at what they did in their previous position, but they are not great at managing people".    Not always an issue, but some teams have to work closely with their counterparts in China and this could mean working later or earlier, due to the time differences. review_title: Good opportunity for experience, but does not support their employees
pros: Working for a growing, global organization brings lots of opportunities for experience. With most groups in the company, you can get as much experience as you want and in a number of different areas. Most everyone in a non-sales department can have the opportunity to get project management experience in one way or another. Process improvement is also highly regarded. Working with international colleagues & strategic partners is good experience for anyone to have in today's business climate.
cons:
Culture clash is highly evident. The China-side of the business is largely separated from the rest, but when you do interface with them they appear to be very helpful and competent. There is a lot of mixing of IBM, Dell, and "other" (i.e., non-IBM/Dell) management styles which ends up making for a very inefficiently-cooperating collection of teams. As a side effect from the IBM business, the major functional groups tend to be very silo'd; a case of the left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing.

Many managers tend to micromanage to the point of suffocation, or being overly strict about enforcing policies. On the other hand, some managers tend to be so far removed from their employees that they don't see each other for months. There is little happy medium in management, so pick your poison.

On the whole, they do not value internal talent and have little long-term focus around their people. For several years following the acquisition, teams were whittled down and positions removed while that workload was added to existing employees, with little regard to the effect on those employees. Some of the more talented people I had the pleasure of working with were either laid off or left due to frustration with management & lack of support or advancement. Performance-based raises were almost non-existent, although at least bonuses performed according to your region's fiscal performance & the overall company's fiscal performance. While one's personal experience would vary greatly depending on the quality of their direct management, in the end, the overall poor leadership & utilization of internal talent would disillusion anyone.

Supply chain issues have been a long term problem that gets attention but is never solved.  

Quota targets can be unreasonable, particularly if you have a good year.  Very difficult to have multiple successful years due to increased quotas.  Sales gates can be unrealistic, which limits the ability to maximize earnings.  Compensation plan is getting worse as the business transitions to Server sales focus.

ISR's spend all their time configuring systems and submitting pricing requests or entering nonsense in to Salesforce to meet minimum activity level measurements.  Very slow response times getting quotes and configurations to customers leads to lost sales and/or very unhappy customers.

Management is focused on one thing right now and that's Servers.  Until IBM's server business deal is completed, Lenovo lacks a competitive Server portfolio.  There's a lot of uncertainty around the IBM acquisition and morale is near or at an all time low.  Despite the current success of the overall company and the contribution of the US, many experienced reps are leaving or looking to leave.

Layoffs or "reorganizations" happen frequently, and seem to have no rhyme or reason. I've seen successful inside reps get laid off before lazy, unsuccessful reps. Constantly "growing" and downsizing. Creating jobs and then cutting those same jobs. Very immature company as a whole for how long they have been around.

You start as a contractor with an even lower salary + capped commission. Management is hit or miss. Some managers are very selective and play favorites. Individuals who are lazy, unproductive, and unresponsive can often be converted to a full time employee before others simply by brown nosing (barely metrics based at all).  Don't get me wrong here - there are some great employees/reps/managers, but they often go unrecognized. 

Once you become full time, you get an extremely modest "pay bump" to your salary (still far below the industry standard for the same role). They say you now have an "uncapped" commission structure, which isn't true. If you are on track to overachieving, management has the ability (and will often do so), provide quota relief to individuals underachieving and tack that on to the ones overachieving to make things "fair". This, in turn, penalizesthose employees who are actually doing well. 

The LASR program is a good concept on paper, but also allows for highly disgruntled employees. What if you were a loyal employee with a company for 2+ years and they hire a recent college grad (with little to no experience) to join your team and do the exact same role as you, but start them at significantly higher pay?

As I stated this is a great "job" for the recent grad who wants to get their feet wet in B2B sales, build experience, grow their personal brand, and move on.. I say "job" because after about a year with the company, I saw no opportunity, and no desire to grow a career within Lenovo and started looking elsewhere.
